urn:contentItem:5NJC-3PN1-JBVR-3497-00000-00Blizzard of embers sparked fires that burned Fort McMurray homes last year2017-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisNATIONALBlizzard of embers sparked fires that burned Fort McMurray homes last yearEmber blizzard sparked Fort McMurray home firesJohn CotterThe Canadian Press

EDMONTON - A wildfire expert says a blizzard of blazing embers that were blown by the wind over fireguards and a river sparked the flames that destroyed homes in Fort McMurray last spring and then spread the destruction deeper into neighbourhoods.

Alan Westhaver says the embers ignited combustible material such as dry grass, leaves, pine needles, fences, patio decks, wood piles, evergreens and ornamental shrubs that were too close to homes in the northern Alberta city.

The smaller blazes set homes on fire and flames then crept to nearby houses in the closely built subdivisions.

"Mass ember production and long-distance transport by strong winds subjected neighbourhoods to intense ember showers," Westhaver wrote in a report for the Institute for Catastrophic Loss Reduction.

"Wind-driven embers from the forest fire likely caused the majority of home ignitions near the urban perimeter which, in turn, likely triggered the massive urban conflagration and losses that followed."

The wildfire forced more than 80,000 people from the area and destroyed more than 2,400 buildings. Insured losses are estimated at about $4 billion.

The report says few homes caught fire due to direct contact with the flames or heat from the burning forest.

"No, this fire was not, at least initially, an insurmountable force that rolled into, and over, an entire community like a smashing tidal wave," said Westhaver.

"Primarily, it was millions of raisin-sized firebrands searching for places to carry on with combustion, and succeeding all too often."

Homes on the edges of neighbourhoods with yards that had less combustible material, including landscaping that kept trees and bushes further away, suffered less damage.

The report suggests that plans to protect communities from wildfires should include preventative action by homeowners.

Westhaver, a former Parks Canada wildfire manager, said building fireguards and clearing trees and bushes outside of communities isn't enough.

More attention must be paid to raising awareness among homeowners and governments about landscaping and building practices that will reduce the risk.

"This progression can only be broken, and disaster avoided, by substantially increasing the proportion of homes that are resistant to ignition - especially by embers," Westhaver said.

"The ignitability of homes and properties is really the weak point."

Other researchers are using computer technology to study the disaster to better understand how wildfires - and embers - behave.

Canadian Forest Service scientists are feeding data about the fire into a computer model known as FIRETEC.

The program allows scientists to set virtual wildfires to study how flames grow and move. It factors in the effects of weather, topography and the types of trees and shrubs burned.

Westhaver's report is providing some data and context for the work, said wildfire scientist Dan Thompson.

The results of the computer program are to be analyzed this fall.

FIRETEC was developed at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico to model fire behaviour in the dry pine forests of the U.S. southwest.

Researchers began modifying the program for use in Canada's boreal forest following the 2011 wildfire that destroyed parts of Slave Lake, Alta.

urn:contentItem:53CD-STD1-F197-51JC-00000-00Salvation Army receives fire evacuees2011-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Salvation Army receives fire evacueesThe Brampton Guardian

The Salvation Army in the Peel region along with Region of Peel officials and the Red Cross are preparing to receive some 1,800 to 2,000 evacuees from various communities in Northern Ontario.

The displaced individuals are those affected by more than 100 forest fires raging in the northwestern Ontario since Wednesday.

The forest fire evacuees are expected to arrive in Peel within the next 12 hours, said Salvation Army officials in a press release.

Salvation Army is gathering clothing, blankets, food, baby supplies, toys and hygiene products for the women and children.

"The Salvation Army is capable of serving some 400 meals every hour and a half through their Emergency Disaster Services Vehicle," said Major John Murray, Salvation Army's divisional secretary for public relations and development.

He said the Salvation Army in communities across Ontario have been put on alert and others such as Ottawa are already responding.

No new fires have begun since a far-reaching electrical storm hit most of northwestern Ontario late Wednesday, Natural Resources Minister Linda Jeffrey told reporters at the Thunder Bay Fire Management headquarters.

There are still 112 fires burning - some are dangerously close to isolated fly-in First Nations communities.

Fire tower operators in Nova Scotia were reporting extremely low visibility.</p><p>Fires also broke out in central New Brunswick, but were quickly brought under control.</p><p>There were also forest fires in Newfoundland. One blaze burned out of control near Bay D'Espoir. fire workers.</p><p>Warm, dry weather is forecast for the rest of the week.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5N8W-VVN1-F105-60XM-00000-00Camp fire ban goes in to effect in the northwest2014-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisOUR TOWNPg. 1Camp fire ban goes in to effect in the northwestEditorial

An area including the region around Kitimat is subject to an open fire and camp fire ban, the Northwest Fire Centre announced today.

The ban is to prevent human-caused wildfires and protect public safety.

The list of banned fires are:

* Category 2 open fires

* Category 3 open fires

* campfires, as defined in the Wildfire Regulation

* outdoor stoves and other portable campfire apparatuses that are not

CSA or ULC approved

* open fires in an outdoor stove

* fireworks, tiki torches and sky lanterns

This prohibition does not apply to cooking stoves that use gas, propane or briquettes. It also does not apply to a portable campfire apparatus with a CSA or ULC rating that uses briquettes, liquid or gaseous fuel, with a flame height of 15 centimetres or less. The use of a portable campfire apparatus that does not meet these conditions is prohibited.

This prohibition covers all BC Parks, Crown and private lands, but does not apply within the boundaries of local governments that have forest fire prevention bylaws and are serviced by a fire department. Please check with local authorities for any other restrictions before lighting a fire.

The fire danger rating in the Northwest Fire Centre currently ranges from "high" to "extreme" and is expected to increase in the coming days, due to forecasted weather conditions. As Wildfire Management

Branch crews and personnel face increasing fire activity from naturally occurring wildfires, it is imperative that preventable, human-caused fires do not add to that workload.

Anyone found in contravention of an open fire prohibition may be issued a ticket for $345 or, if convicted in court, be fined up to $100,000 and sentenced to one year in jail. If the contravention causes or contributes to a wildfire, the person may be subject to a penalty of up to $10,000 and be ordered to pay all firefighting and associated costs.

British Columbia

Man, 24, arrested after suspected feud leaves

3 dead and 2 wounded

Police have arrested a 24-year-old in connection with a weekend shooting that left three men dead, two others wounded and aboriginal communities in the Okanagan in shock.

The RCMP said in a news release the suspect was arrested yesterday morning without incident, but they are not releasing his name or any other details. The Penticton Herald has reported there was speculation a longtime feud involving the six may have culminated in the killings. Sources told the newspaper one man allegedly shot the five others in anger after being kicked out of the group.

The men killed in the violence were Quincy Paul, 29, and Robin Baptiste, 24, both of Penticton, and 20-year-old Damien Endreny of Oliver.

Woman who dropped baby over bridge settles lawsuit

A woman who dropped her disabled infant daughter over the edge of a popular suspension bridge has settled a lawsuit with the bridge operators.

"Under the agreement, Capilano Suspension Bridge expressly denies liability and is released from all claims," the operators of the tourist attraction said in a news release yesterday. Nadia Hama's 17-month-old daughter, Kaya, miraculously survived after tree branches broke her 50-metre plunge into the rocky canyon below the bridge.

Newfoundland

Government brings in $250 home heating fuel rebate

The government has announced a home heating fuel rebate of $250 for low-income seniors and individuals, as well as seniors.

The rebate applies to furnace oil, stove oil and propane. Finance Minister Loyola Sullivan said yesterday that the government brought in the program because of the volatile nature of oil prices.

Ontario

Forest fire season hits

a new low, ministry says

The forest fire season in Ontario has officially ended, setting a new low for the number of fires across the province this year.

Between April 1 and Oct. 31, 426 fires were recorded across the province, said Bob Thomas of the Ministry of Natural Resources. That's 110 fewer than the previous low of 536 fires set back in 1928.

"We're just trying to hit this fire before the day heats up.''</p><p nitf:lede="true">Dense smoke from the fire forced the evacuation of about 1,600 people from Leaf Rapids Sunday evening.</p><p>Innkeepers down the road from the town about 1,000 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg readied rooms Sunday evening for the evacuees.</p><p>"I'm doing a lot of baking right now,'' said Hilda Merasty, who was preparing bread and cookies for evacuees at the Friendship Centre in Lynn Lake, about an hour's drive northwest of Leaf Rapids.</p><p>Almost everyone in Leaf Rapids was given two hours to pack and leave when the fire swept to within three kilometres of the community, town administrator Ernie Epp said Sunday night.</p><p>Only about 75 essential workers remained the town this morning, Bon said.</p><p>The fire has cut off the two-lane, gravel road that links Leaf Rapids to Thompson, said Bon. That meant people had to flee 100 kilometres north to Lynn Lake.</p><p>It's a scenario that has been played out several times over the years, with each town helping the other when fire threatens.</p><p>Last summer, a massive fire forced 850 residents of Lynn Lake to seek shelter in Leaf Rapids and Thompson.</p><p>In 1989, more than 1,000 residents from Leaf Rapids bunked with Lynn Lake families when fires forced them to flee their homes.</p><p>Sheldon Lambe, his pregnant wife Margie and 2 1/2-year-old daughter Jessica got one of the last hotel rooms available Sunday night in Lynn Lake.</p><p>"It's been a pretty harrowing night,'' Lambe said. His wife is already a few days overdue, he added.</p><p>"We packed whatever we could squeeze in the car, right down to my daughter's Barney.''</p><p>A lightning strike may have started the fire Saturday amid unseasonably hot, dry conditions, according to Epp. However, Bon said forestry officials suspect it was man-made.</p><p>"The fire started (Saturday) on about 25 hectares or so,'' he said. "Unfortunately, it got away on the ground crew.''</p><p>By Sunday, the blaze was out of control and had spread over 2,000 hectares. Water bombers that were scheduled to be put away for the winter and routine maintenance were hurried into service.</p><p>People in Leaf Rapids, a town surrounded by dense woods on the banks of the Churchill River, were warned earlier Sunday on the local cable television channel to be prepared to leave.</p><p>"It looked like thunderclouds,'' Lambe said of the thick smoke enveloping the town.</p><p>There were long lineups at gas pumps as people rushed to gas stations to fill up their vehicles for the hour-long drive north to Lynn Lake.</p><p>When winds started to shift, Epp - who is also the town's emergency co-ordinator - ordered residents to evacuate.</p><p>Lambe, who works at the Hudson Bay Mining Company's Ruttan Mine, said officials closed the mine before the evacuation notice was given.</p><p>And when it came, Lambe's family was ready. Besides clothes, they also packed their wedding videos and pictures - "things that if they're lost, they're gone forever,'' Lambe said.</p><p>"I just bought a new house, I'm hoping they can contain it.''</p><p>Volunteers went door-to-door alerting people to leave town and fire trucks cruised the streets blaring the same message.</p><p>Evacuees booked ahead for rooms at Lynn Lake's two hotels. Others were to be put up at the Friendship Centre, the town's high school gym and at private residences, said the centre's Merasty.</p><p>And she was ready for them. "We'll probably have a good time.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - A forest fire the size of Toronto continued its rampage through northern Alberta on Tuesday, wiping out a tiny hamlet and forcing 250 residents of two other communities from their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- The massive fire, burning along a 67-kilometre path about 200 kilometres north of Edmonton, razed nine homes in Chisholm overnight and forced the evacuation of nearby Hondo and Smith.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Provincial fire officials said 55 firefighters risked their lives trying to save Chisholm, but were forced to pull out as the fire roared down on them and huge chunks of burning embers began to fall in the hamlet.</p><p>"Our firefighters worked all night,'' Rick Strickland, provincial fire information officer, said in Edmonton. "Their lives indeed were threatened. In some cases, they should have been out of there earlier.''</p><p>Residents had been evacuated the previous day.</p><p>The intense smoke and heat from the blaze, which is whipping flames more than 125 metres in the air and rocketing burning embers up to 10 kilometres in front of its advance, forced even water bombers to back off as it descended upon the hamlet.</p><p>Residents were to be allowed back Tuesday to survey the smoking ruins.</p><p>The fire was burning within five kilometres of Hondo and eight kilometres of Smith, two villages where 75 families had been evacuated.</p><p>Fire officials described the Chisholm blaze as one of the most explosive and erratic fires in Alberta in decades.</p><p>It raced 34 kilometres toward the town of Slave Lake in a matter of hours Monday before the winds shifted to send it back in the opposite direction.</p><p>Strickland said several fire crews have had to be evacuated at sudden notice to avoid being trapped by the fire.</p><p>While the 660-square-kilometre fire is not the largest in provincial history, it is one of the worst firefighters have had to contend with in a populated area, he said.</p><p>Strickland said the energy generated by the blaze is equivalent to a nuclear explosion.</p><p>"It is a very serious interface fire that we're experiencing today,'' he said.</p><p>The Chisholm fire has already destroyed one railway trestle and is thought to have destroyed three others.</p><p>So far the province has spent $4 million trying to contain the blaze out of the $25 million it has expended on fires so far this year, he said.</p><p>The fire has been split into two sections with an Alberta fire team overseeing the original fire and an Ontario team overseeing the western portion that started Monday.</p><p>Fire crews were setting up a fireguard between Highway 2 and the Athabasca River to try to stop the flames from advancing, Strickland said.</p><p>About 335 firefighters, 24 helicopters, 52 bulldozers and 32 water trucks have been deployed against the fire. More than 700 firefighters, including crews from Manitoba, British Columbia and Saskatchewan, were fighting fires in the province Tuesday along with air tanker teams from the Yukon and Northwest Territories.</p><p>Strickland said the province may have to call in the Armed Forces or seek help from the United States once it exhausts its supply of Canadian provincial firefighters.</p><p>So far about 1,200 people have been evacuated as a result of 37 fires across the province. One fire near Redwater, about 50 kilometres northeast of Edmonton, destroyed two homes.</p><p>Officials lifted an evacuation alert Tuesday for the 7,000 residents of Slave Lake because winds had changed. Two areas east of town - Poplar Estates and the Mitsue Industrial Park - were still on alert, said Slave Lake Mayor Gerry Allarie.</p><p>"The winds have shifted to the southwest from the southeast, so it's not blowing the fire towards us at all right now,'' he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5RYG-8PV1-F105-63WG-00000-00Our editor sends dispatches from the United Nations, Part 22018-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1Our editor sends dispatches from the United Nations, Part 2

UNITED NATIONS - A province in Canada is actively creating another Highway of Tears in our country.

I am with two Huntsville High School students at the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women this week. We are here representing YWCA Muskoka, through YWCA Canada, making up a part of the Canadian delegation to the commission.

The focus this year is on the particular concerns and challenges rural women face around the world.

We are attending official discussions at the UN as well as side and parallel events in other locations in New York City.

See an account of the first session we attended here.

The second session we attended, Highway of Tears: Gender-based violence in rural/northern Canada was put on by YWCA Canada.

Leaders from rural YWCAs shared promising practices that address gender-based violence for rural women who have limited access to transportation, services and work in precarious jobs.

"Indigenous women and girls face a disproportionate share of gender violence and hate in Canada."

The YWCA is also exploring strategies women are using to push back against trafficking in rural and northern communities.

It was standing-room-only in the venue.

Donna Brooks spoke from YWCA in Prince Albert. Since 1912 this YWCA has been a leading provider of housing and services for the most vulnerable people in that community.

We heard from her that the rural bus transportation system in Saskatchewan, long hailed as one of the best in the country, has been closed down by the province as a "cost-saving measure." One that is costing the province much more in the long run and is putting the rural community at terrible risk.

It is creating a whole new Highway of Tears for Canada. Indigenous and rural women no longer have any transportation. When they face violence, which they do at an alarming rate, they have to get to Prince Albert for services.

For many that means putting themselves at great risk by hitch hiking, trading sex for transportation or losing the chance to escape at all.

We heard that it used to cost a rural person $70 a month to access bus services into larger hubs for things like medical treatment. Now there are ads on Kijiji offering $300 for a ride to attend chemotherapy treatments. And anecdotal information from the medical community indicates that people just aren't making their medical appointments. Only pain and suffering can result from this.

There have been protests throughout the province as lives are endangered and lost, and communities are plunged into isolation by the cutting off of their public transportation.

Amanda Kanbari from YWCA Yellowknife talked about how climate change is making things worse for rural women in that province. The increased temperatures and shorter winters have meant longer, more treacherous forest fire seasons. In 2014 smoke from forest fires blotted out the sun and scorched the highway, meaning neither food nor supplies were coming in or out.

Domestic violence in that vast, sparsely populated province is eight times higher than in the rest of the country.

When women escape, they do so by snowmobile and because of climate change that option is reduced.

Amanda spoke of women hiding and waiting for the next plane so they could fly out, but when they arrive at the airport their abusive partner is there - waiting.

urn:contentItem:5SVM-VBJ1-JDH3-G2WT-00000-00Current forest fires bring back memories of 2003 wildfire in Kelowna2018-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisNEWSCurrent forest fires bring back memories of 2003 wildfire in KelownaAlistair Waters

For two Kelowna men who were front and centre during the Okanagan Mountain Park wildfire 15 years ago, the current forest fire situation in the Okanagan is hitting a little too close to home.

Former Kelowna fire chief Gerry Zimmerman and former City of Kelowna city manager Ron Mattiussi say the current fire burning in Okanagan Mountain Park on the east side of Okanagan Lake not only brings back memories, it's also a concern.

"Ultimately, these fires are wind-driven events," said Mattiussi, who spent days in the emergency operations centre set up in Kelowna to co-ordinate the firefighter response to the 2003 wildfire. "It's Mother Nature."

That fire destroyed more than 240 homes in southern part of the city, several historic Kettle Valley Rail trestles in Myra Canyon and forced the evacuation of 30,000 people from the Mission area of Kelowna.

Zimmerman, who was the city's fire chief during that pivotal moment in Kelowna's history agrees—shifts in the wind can change a fire's behaviour quickly, and dramatically.

He said Friday he remembers flying in a helicopter over the 2003 fire when it was still confined to the park and the wind appeared to be pushing it towards Naramata to the south.

He said he was being concerned for the small rural community it appeared to be heading toward.

"But by the time we landed and I got back to the fire hall, the wind had shifted and was blowing the flames towards Kelowna," said Zimmermann. "And you know what happened next."

Related: Okanagan Wildfires: The latest on wildfires and evacuations

As someone who has been there and done that when it comes to fighting an intense wildfire threatening a city, Zimmermann said he believes the best approach to all forest fires is "hit them with everything you've got from the start," and not let them burn unabated, even if they are considered well away from buildings and humans.

"Not everyone agrees with me on that, but that's how I feel," said Zimmermann.

In 2003, because the fire was burning outside of the Kelowna Fire Department's jurisdiction at the start, his advice went unheeded and he was powerless to change that approach.

Today he says he still feels the same way.

"Hit it hard right away regardless of jurisdiction or cost. Figure all that out later."

Mattiussi said he understands the sentiment but this time around there are other major fires burning in the area at the same time and, in the case of the Mt. Eneas fire just south of Peachland, they are threatening buildings.

So prioritization of resources may be an issue, he said.

"I'm not going to second guess anyone. I know these guys are trying real hard."

Zimmermann said he is not trying to be critical of any current decision, but said the Good Creek fire currently burning in Okanagan Mountain Park is eerily similar to the early stages of the 2003 fire. Both started with lightening strikes and were allowed to burn for days before they became a serious threat.

But, according to Mattiussi, unlike 15 years ago, the area is not as dry as it was back then when the area had not seen any serious precipitation for several weeks, the temperature was very high, it was later in the summer, the humidity level was very low and the winds constantly very strong.

Related: Updated: Complete list of B.C. Interior wildfire coverage

In addition to the fires south of Peachland and in Okanagan Mountain Park, there is a also a serious growing fire burning near Summerland. All three blazes are fires of note for the B.C. Wildfire Service.

Flying water tankers, ground crews and heavy equipment are all being used to fight the three fires and all three remain out of control.

More than 40 homes have been evacuated because of the Peachland-area fire and 656 homes are on evacuation alert. The fire is estimated at 1,000 hectares.

Other smaller fires in the area include one near Law Creek southwest of Glenrosa in West Kelowna that has prompted an evacuation alert for 198 properties in the upper Glenrosa area.

urn:contentItem:5PT4-DVP1-DY9S-T1KR-00000-00B.C. auditor takes aim at inadequate management of grizzly populations2017-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisNATIONALB.C. auditor takes aim at inadequate management of grizzly populationsB.C. grizzly management inadequate: auditorDirk MeissnerThe Canadian Press

VICTORIA - Hunters in British Columbia kill up to 300 grizzly bears every year, but it is habitat loss that is actually the greatest threat to the imposing predators, says auditor general Carol Bellringer in a report.

Growing communities, roads created to expand the forest industry, and oil and gas development in remote areas pose larger dangers to the overall health and growth of the species, says the report released Tuesday.

Bellringer's audit of the B.C. government's grizzly management plan found an absence of provincial monitoring and inventory strategies, and incomplete commitments to save grizzly populations, estimated at 15,000 provincewide.

"While government has undertaken activities to conserve grizzly bears, some of their commitments have gone unfulfilled," the report says. "These include identifying and securing key grizzly bear habitats, creating a grizzly bear management plan and implementing a recovery plan for the North Cascades grizzly bear population."

Bellringer's report makes 10 recommendations, including reviewing legislation to clarify the management and protection roles of the Forests and Environment ministries to reduce overlapping responsibilities.

The New Democrat government says it accepts all the recommendations and promises to develop a grizzly bear management plan with clear objectives, roles and responsibilities.

"Grizzly bear populations in some areas of B.C. are increasing, but this is likely happening independently from an adequate management framework," the report says. "We did find that the greatest risk to grizzly bears isn't the hunt, it's the degradation of grizzly bear habitat."

Bellringer said B.C. is one of the last areas in North America where the bears live in their natural habitat. She said the health of the bears is important because they are an indicator of how well other species and ecosystems are doing.

Community and industrial development in habitat areas makes it difficult for the bears to find food and raise their young, which results in increased human-bear conflicts, the report says. Between 2006 and 2015, 389 grizzly bears died in such conflicts.

Bellringer said B.C.'s vast network of resource roads, estimated at 600,000 kilometres and growing by 10,000 kilometres annually, threatens grizzly populations by allowing easy human access to wilderness areas.

"Unfortunately, this results in increased illegal killing of grizzly bears and more human-bear conflicts," she said at a news conference. "And yet, long-promised legislation that could address this risk is not yet in place."

Forests Minister Doug Donaldson said the government will move incrementally to address access issues to bear zones. Laws that allow the government to restrict access to hunting areas and forest fire zones could be used to limit movements in grizzly habitat, he added.

"The nice thing about this report from my perspective is it lays the groundwork for what is a very strategic issue for us and that's creating a new approach to wildlife management and habitat conservation in this province," Donaldson told a conference call with reporters.

Environment Minister George Heyman said the government will hire more conservation officers next year to help conduct grizzly management work.

"We have seen over the last decade-and-a-half a significant decrease in what many people refer to as boots on the ground, our ability to assess risk, our ability to assess numbers of species, to implement conservation measures," he said.

The government announced a ban on grizzly trophy hunting in August. In 2015, the government issued about 1,700 grizzly hunting permits to B.C. residents and about 200 permits to non-resident hunters.

urn:contentItem:5VBN-3NC1-F103-3229-00000-00Vinay Menon: Canada needs a wall to keep out Americans like Bill Nye2019-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENTPg. 0Vinay Menon: Canada needs a wall to keep out Americans like Bill NyeVinay Menon

<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/entertainment/opinion/2019/02/01/canada-needs-a-wall-to-keep-out-americans-like-bill-nye/billnye.jpg"/><br/>Bill Nye should change his nickname to the "Not Helping Guy."At least, that's what we should call him in Canada. He can still be "Bill Nye the Science Guy" in America. But on this side of the border, it's time to rebrand this shifty, pandering, ideological bow-tied edutainer as "Bill Nye the Not Helping Guy."You ever listen to someone mention a problem and then casually segue into a cause-and-effect aside that, quite unexpectedly, involves you?

My wife does this all the time. She'll say something like, "Wednesday is my only free night to sort out the furnace."Then when I nod while glued to CNN and not really paying attention, she'll add: "So that means you're taking the girls to dance class."She once started a story about Myanmar that ended with me descaling the Keurig. I once donated clothing to Goodwill after she outlined a harrowing chimpanzee crisis in Africa, even though apes don't wear denim and my furnace seems to be just fine. The point is: every problem has an unexpected consequence.Take climate change. Amid the polar vortex that left parts of America colder than Antarctica this week, Nye was interviewed on MSNBC's <em>Hardball With Chris Matthews.</em> It was like watching two Scientologists high-five about KRC triangles.After condemning skeptics as "patently wrong," Nye riffed on the threats climate change poses to agriculture. Pests are showing up earlier in the growing season and sticking around longer. True. Farmers are using more pesticides and manual extraction as they're forced to declare war on pestilence and rogue weeds. Also true.But then he said this: "Growing in North America, which is the bread basket of the world even now, the agriculture in North America is going to have to move north, into what would nominally be Canada. And we don't have the infrastructure. We don't have the railroads and roads to get food from that area to where we need it around the world."That's when it hit me: Bill Nye the Not Helping Guy is officially off his rocker.First of all, as a proud Canadian, I must take great exception to the use of "nominally," which the Oxford Dictionary defines as "in name only; officially though perhaps not in reality." Sir, was that the intended meaning? That Canada is a nation in name only, one that does not exist in physical reality? That we are but a conquerable splotch on a scalable map in which sovereignty is forfeited should our arable lands be needed to provide sustenance for victims of global climate change?<em>Victims that</em> <em>do not include us?</em>The language in that quote is striking.Which is why, to me, he is now Bill Nye the Not Helping Guy. He thinks Canada is a developing nation. At that moment on MSNBC, Canada was a Foot Locker in a region where nobody has feet. We were a 7-Eleven serving those who can't digest Slurpees. We were a smoke alarm with no sensors, an airplane without wings, a rocking chair cemented to the floor.How else might we explain Nye's irrational fear about the lack of railroads and roads that could carry food beyond our imaginary borders?Honestly, I'm tempted to call him up and say I'm out of milk just to hear him reply: "Well, it's cold out there. Be careful when you untether your donkey and ride into the town square. And take a compass. Those dirt paths are hazardous. Also, you might want to reduce your liquid intake until Canada has indoor plumbing. During a polar vortex, your pee pee could very easily freeze your wee wee!"With all this wall talk, I'm starting to think it is Canada that needs a wall.You know, a physical barrier to keep out America, to keep out people such Bill Nye the Not Helping Guy. Whatever his pop-cultural genius, whatever his good intentions for humanity, that quote betrayed an ignorance more startling than any forest fire or Category 5 hurricane or once-in-a-generation polar vortex.Canada is already up to our poutine-stained lips with problems now involving various bad actors - China, Cuba, Netflix - and now Nye is now shifting the burden of continental food production onto our primitive shoulders? America has already swallowed our culture. Now they want our food?Build a wall, Justin Trudeau! Or promise to build a wall, Andrew Scheer!Now that one of America's most popular personalities thinks Canada is basically a free farmland for the taking, it is time to get real and realize how we are viewed.The science is clear in the double-negative: we will never not be taken for granted.And if climate change gets any worse, we are the ones who need the wall.<span class="endnote_contrib">Vinay Menon is the Star's pop culture columnist based in Toronto. urn:contentItem:5VYK-2PB1-JDH1-C22H-00000-00The territory is aware of climate change impacts, says Pillai2019-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:20:59ZLexisNexisNEWSThe territory is aware of climate change impacts, says Pillai

Energy Mines and Resources Minister Ranj Pillai insists the territorial government is well aware of the impact of climate change and is moving forward with renewable energy options.

"We understand the threat we have right now," he said in an April 16 interview adding that research and work into those options takes time and the day-to-day efforts to get there aren't always obvious.

"We understand the threat (as a result of climate change) we have right now," he said.

Collecting data on wind is one example of that, he said, pointing to a project underway in Carcross. To get accurate information that may determine the possibility of future wind projects, the data collection stage alone is a total of two years.

Pillai was responding to comments made at the April 15 Whitehorse city council meeting by delegates J.P. Pinard and Yukoners Concerned chair Don Roberts who called for greater action by the city and territory to move towards renewable energy use.

Pinard is an engineer focused on wind energy while Yukoners Concerned is an organization that has been urging a move away from fossil fuels in favour of renewable energy.

As Pinard said he would like to see the half of the non-renewable energy used by the territory replaced with renewable energy sources by 2030.

There's potential for hydro, wind and biomass, he said noting his interest in wind storage and pointing to a project being pursued by the Chu Níikwän Development Corporation to expand wind generation on Haeckel Hill.

Fire smarting efforts could not only address the potential for forest fires, but also create the wood waste required for biomass.

Raven Recycling is already using biomass energy at its Marwell location and the Teslin Tlingit Council is using a biomass boiler to heat 10 buildings in the community.

"The seasonality of forest fire work can compliment the winter fire-smart work that is needed to protect our communities," he said. "All wood taken from fire-smarting can be the feedstock for your space heating needs. Both Raven Recycling and the Teslin Tlingit Council have proven that we have the technology and knowhow to burn local wood efficiently.

Pinard said all governments need to work transitioning to renewable energy.

"I am proposing to you to approach your First Nations government partners and reach a deal to help you meet your energy needs with their renewable resources."

He went on to suggest the city should take a lead in creating a working group that could help "build the Yukon's renewable energy economy".

Roberts highlighted the 2019 Canada's Changing Climate Report released April 1 showing Canada is warming twice as fast as the rest of the world with a greater impact being felt in the North.

"We are in a climate change emergency," Roberts said, echoing the stance taken by a number of communities across the country - including Old Crow - which is to declare a climate change emergency next month.

"Yukon is experiencing dramatic and rapid temperature change and faces increased risk of catastrophic wildfire," Roberts said. "Permafrost melting is degrading infrastructure. Environmental changes are stressing wildlife already challenged by the arrival of invasive animal, insect and plant species."

Throughout his presentation, Roberts focused on the Yukon government, issuing an invite to Pillai to have a public meeting before the end of May "to discuss how and when the Yukon Government plans to transition - in a significant manner - to renewable energy."

He also questioned the territory's plans to access the federal Arctic Energy Fund.

"Another option, among many to publicly discuss, is legislation to commit Yukon Energy, in the development of future energy projects, to a target of 100 per cent renewable energy."

Pillai said he has met with Yukoners Concerned previously and has outlined the work already underway to move to more renewable energy, stressing the process to get there.

The government has to have an Independent Power Production Policy in place before any renewable power produced can be sold back to the grid, he pointed out. That meant a process to draft that document.

Similarly, to access the Arctic Energy Fund, a framework has to be in place and then applications by project proponents have to be drafted to access the funding.

"There's applications being prepared," he said.

And then there are initiatives already underway - the purchasing agreement signed between ATCO Electric Yukon Ltd. and the Vuntut Gwitchin First Nation for the energy produced by the solar array owned by the First Nation. It's anticipated that could mean some days during summer in the territory's northern-most community that the diesel generators are turned off.

"We're pretty excited for the project in Old Crow," Pillai said.

Efforts are also underway at the Yukon Development Corporation to explore how renewable energy can be stored. There are a number of issues around snowmelt to consider when it comes to renewable storage. It may be that battery power will be required for storage, something that is being looked at.

"That's the kind of work we're trying to do," he said

He also pointed out there are times when 98 per cent of the territory's energy is being produced by renewable resources.

Though the Yukon's not at a place to go rely completely on renewable resources just yet - the lights still need to come on in January, Pilli pointed out - he believes there will someday be an opportunity to go 100 per cent renewable as innovation and technology improves.
